doc.title: Sweden NIER survey: Higher confidence, lower inflation
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM/Sweden NIER survey Higher confidence lower inflationSweden NIER survey Higher confidence lower inflation_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM

passages.text: The headline ETI index increased 1.7pts to 96.0 in August, the highest since February The July- August average is, however, consistent with sluggish growth at \(0.6\% \mathrm{q / q}\) saar Confidence across all business sectors and among consumers improved slightly, but the latter remained depressed Job indicators pointed to a still- weak labor market Price plans fell. There was a particularly large drop among retailers, an index closely watched by the Riksbank... ...in turn making the survey dovish on net. Our view of core inflation falling below target in 2026 has strengthened

The NIER survey for August showed the headline ETI indicator rising 1.7pts to 96.0, the highest since February. According to our models, this equates to GDP growth at \(0.8\% \mathrm{q / q}\) saar, though the July- August average is a bit lower at \(0.6\%\) . This is below our 3Q GDP forecast ( \(1.75\%\) ) and the Riksbank's ( \(1.4\%\) ) which includes a large \(3.5\%\) increase for 2Q).

A caveat to this, however, is that the NIER survey is not great at predicting GDP growth for a specific quarter. Rather, it is good at capturing the trend. Looking at the average in 2025, the ETI indicator equates to \(0.6\%\) saar. Given that 1H25 GDP contracted \(- 0.6\%\) saar, this means that 3Q GDP would have to increase \(1.2\%\) saar to align with the ETI indicator, on average, in 2025.

Household confidence edged up 0.4pts, albeit remaining at the still- depressed level of 91 (a level below 100 should be interpreted as "weaker confidence than normal" and a level at 90 as "much weaker confidence than normal"). Details were less encouraging as household expectations over the next 12 months for both their own financial positions as well as the economy declined. One possible cause was that the perception of inflation increased. The overall level in August was around 1 standard deviation below its long- run average. This is likely to once again be one of the lowest across DMs (see chart).

Turning to the business side, all the main indices increased (see table). Trade posted the largest increase and thereby moved above the 100 threshold, in turn contributing to total business sector confidence being close to normal at 99.8. The retail trade index is a good indicator of actual retail sales (see charts). The index
See page 5 for analyst certification and important disclosures.

posted a solid gain in August, pointing to a retail sales rebound in 3Q after recording the largest contraction in over 30 years in May. As has been the case since May, manufacturing companies were asked about tariffs. More companies than in July reported that production volumes had declined because of tariffs (and uncertainty).

Labour market indicators were mixed. Total hiring intentions moved out of negative territory, aligning stagnant job growth. The improvement was broad- based across sectors (though trade and manufacturing remained negative). Employment in the "past few months" – which in recent years has had a much better correlation with actual employment – fell from - 4 to - 5. The decline was led by services and trade. Given these sectors are more job- intensive, this was somewhat concerning.

On the nominal side, price plans for the total industry and the retail index – both closely watched by the Riksbank – declined. Both now sit close to their long- run averages, aligning with inflation below 2% (see charts). In particular, the retail index sent a strong signal of disinflation ahead, dropping 13pts to 18. The decline was driven by wholesale food. This index has collapsed from a very high level of 85 in March to - 7 in August (see charts).

With the NIER data now available, our newly introduced Riksbank Sentiment Indicator showed a rebound in August, but remained in negative territory (chart below). The rebound was mostly caused by higher inflation expectations in the Origo Survey (the NIER survey made a minor positive contribution in August). The indicator, which in a simple way tries to measure demand and price indicators closely watched by the Riksbank, has a solid track record of predicting policy rate changes. The current level is historically aligned with rate cuts, although not a deep easing cycle.
Riksbank Sentiment Indicator (constructed by JPM)

Source: J.Morgan, SCB, Riksbank, NIER, Origo. \(^{\ast}\mathrm{Z}\) scores of NIER industry demand exp., NIER industry price exp., HH conf., Origo 5-year CPI exp. The four variables have equal weights.

The August survey was close to our expectations, giving something to both the hawks and doves. On net, however, we think the Riksbank will assess the survey to be dovish. The largest change was the drop in retailers' price plans, which the Board traditionally has been very focused on. At the same time, labor market indicators and household confidence remained depressed. While the upturn in business confidence is encouraging, the level is still clearly below what is consistent with the Riksbank's optimistic GDP forecast. According to the Board, a strong demand recovery is likely needed to prevent inflation from dropping below 2% in the medium term. Based on today's survey, our conviction of core inflation falling
Swedish Economic Tendency Indicator survey
Source: NIER, J.P. Morgan. Weight contributions to headline ETI are in parentheses.
